natural problem: Geoff and Trevor each roll a fair six-sided die.  What is the probability that the product of the numbers they roll is even?
natural solution: There are $6 \times 6 = 36$ possible outcomes. The only way that they can roll an odd product is if both their rolls are odd. Since 3 of the 6 faces on each die are odd, this can occur in $3 \times 3 = 9$ ways.
So a even product can occur in $36-9= 27$ ways, and the probability is thus $\dfrac{27}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac34}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes even_product_probability :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> even_product_probability"
and h1 : "even_product_probability \<le> 1"
and h2 : "even_product_probability = (\<Sum>(i,j)\<in>{(i::nat, j::nat). i \<in> {1..6} \<and> j \<in> {1..6} \<and> (i * j) mod 2 = 0}. (1/6) * (1/6))"
shows  "even_product_probability = 3 / 4"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Geoff and Trevor each roll a fair six-sided die.  What is the probability that the product of the numbers they roll is even? The final Answer is \dfrac34
 ### Proof
 There are $6 \times 6 = 36$ possible outcomes. The only way that they can roll an odd product is if both their rolls are odd. Since 3 of the 6 faces on each die are odd, this can occur in $3 \times 3 = 9$ ways.
 So a even product can occur in $36-9= 27$ ways, and the probability is thus $\dfrac{27}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac34}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes even_product_probability :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> even_product_probability"
and h1 : "even_product_probability \<le> 1"
and h2 : "even_product_probability = (\<Sum>(i,j)\<in>{(i::nat, j::nat). i \<in> {1..6} \<and> j \<in> {1..6} \<and> (i * j) mod 2 = 0}. (1/6) * (1/6))"
shows  "even_product_probability = 3 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the probability of getting an even product when rolling two fair six-sided dice. The final answer is $\frac{3}{4}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> prob x \<and> prob x \<le> 1"
and h1 : "prob x = (\<Sum>(i, j) \<in> {(i, j). i \<in> {1..6} \<and> j \<in> {1..6} \<and> even (i * j)}. 1 / 36)"
shows  "prob x = 3 / 4"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Geoff and Trevor each roll a fair six-sided die.  What is the probability that the product of the numbers they roll is even? The final Answer is \dfrac34
 ### Proof
 There are $6 \times 6 = 36$ possible outcomes. The only way that they can roll an odd product is if both their rolls are odd. Since 3 of the 6 faces on each die are odd, this can occur in $3 \times 3 = 9$ ways.
 So a even product can occur in $36-9= 27$ ways, and the probability is thus $\dfrac{27}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac34}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> prob x \<and> prob x \<le> 1"
and h1 : "prob x = (\<Sum>(i, j) \<in> {(i, j). i \<in> {1..6} \<and> j \<in> {1..6} \<and> even (i * j)}. 1 / 36)"
shows  "prob x = 3 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a game where two six-sided dice are rolled, find the probability that the product of the numbers rolled is even. The final answer is $\frac{3}{4}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 < P"
and h1 : "P \<le> 1"
and h2 : "P = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..6} . \<Sum> j \<in> {1..6} . if even (i * j) then 1 else 0) / 36"
shows  "P = 3 / 4"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Geoff and Trevor each roll a fair six-sided die.  What is the probability that the product of the numbers they roll is even? The final Answer is \dfrac34
 ### Proof
 There are $6 \times 6 = 36$ possible outcomes. The only way that they can roll an odd product is if both their rolls are odd. Since 3 of the 6 faces on each die are odd, this can occur in $3 \times 3 = 9$ ways.
 So a even product can occur in $36-9= 27$ ways, and the probability is thus $\dfrac{27}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac34}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 < P"
and h1 : "P \<le> 1"
and h2 : "P = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..6} . \<Sum> j \<in> {1..6} . if even (i * j) then 1 else 0) / 36"
shows  "P = 3 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a probability $P$ such that $0 < P \leq 1$, find the value of $P$ if it represents the probability of getting an even product when rolling two fair six-sided dice. The final answer is $\frac{3}{4}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability"
and h1 : "probability \<le> 1"
and h2 : "probability = (\<Sum> (i,j) \<in> { (x,y). x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> even (x * y) }. real (1/36))"
shows  "probability = 3/4"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Geoff and Trevor each roll a fair six-sided die.  What is the probability that the product of the numbers they roll is even? The final Answer is \dfrac34
 ### Proof
 There are $6 \times 6 = 36$ possible outcomes. The only way that they can roll an odd product is if both their rolls are odd. Since 3 of the 6 faces on each die are odd, this can occur in $3 \times 3 = 9$ ways.
 So a even product can occur in $36-9= 27$ ways, and the probability is thus $\dfrac{27}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac34}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability"
and h1 : "probability \<le> 1"
and h2 : "probability = (\<Sum> (i,j) \<in> { (x,y). x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> even (x * y) }. real (1/36))"
shows  "probability = 3/4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A pair of six-sided dice is rolled. What is the probability that the product of the numbers rolled is even? The final answer is $\frac{3}{4}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<lambda>x. 1 / 6)"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> is_int x"
and h2 : "finite {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6}"
and h3 : "prob_space (count_space {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6})"
and h4 : "indep_events {prob} {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6}"
shows  "prob {x. (x mod 2 = 0) \<and> (1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6)} * prob {x. (x mod 2 = 0) \<and> (1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6)} = 3 / 4"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Geoff and Trevor each roll a fair six-sided die.  What is the probability that the product of the numbers they roll is even? The final Answer is \dfrac34
 ### Proof
 There are $6 \times 6 = 36$ possible outcomes. The only way that they can roll an odd product is if both their rolls are odd. Since 3 of the 6 faces on each die are odd, this can occur in $3 \times 3 = 9$ ways.
 So a even product can occur in $36-9= 27$ ways, and the probability is thus $\dfrac{27}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac34}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<lambda>x. 1 / 6)"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> is_int x"
and h2 : "finite {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6}"
and h3 : "prob_space (count_space {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6})"
and h4 : "indep_events {prob} {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6}"
shows  "prob {x. (x mod 2 = 0) \<and> (1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6)} * prob {x. (x mod 2 = 0) \<and> (1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6)} = 3 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Consider a fair six-sided die. The probability of rolling an even number is $\frac{1}{2}$. If we roll the die twice, what is the probability of rolling an even number both times? The final answer is $\frac{3}{4}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "nat set" and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A = {a. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> even a}"
and h1 : "B = {b. b \<in> {1..6} \<and> even b}"
and h2 : "\<forall> a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> P a b = 1 / 36"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> (a, b). P a b) (SIGMA a:A. B) = 3 / 4"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Geoff and Trevor each roll a fair six-sided die.  What is the probability that the product of the numbers they roll is even? The final Answer is \dfrac34
 ### Proof
 There are $6 \times 6 = 36$ possible outcomes. The only way that they can roll an odd product is if both their rolls are odd. Since 3 of the 6 faces on each die are odd, this can occur in $3 \times 3 = 9$ ways.
 So a even product can occur in $36-9= 27$ ways, and the probability is thus $\dfrac{27}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac34}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "nat set" and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A = {a. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> even a}"
and h1 : "B = {b. b \<in> {1..6} \<and> even b}"
and h2 : "\<forall> a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> P a b = 1 / 36"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> (a, b). P a b) (SIGMA a:A. B) = 3 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Consider two sets of even numbers, $A$ and $B$, each containing numbers from 1 to 6. The probability $P(a, b)$ of selecting a pair of numbers $(a, b)$, with $a$ from set $A$ and $b$ from set $B$, is $\frac{1}{36}$. Find the sum of the probabilities of all possible pairs of numbers $(a, b)$ from the sets $A$ and $B$. The final answer is $\frac{3}{4}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> p"
and h1 : "p \<le> 1"
and h2 : "p = (\<Sum> (x, y) \<in> {1..6} \<times> {1..6}. if even (x * y) then 1 else 0) / (6 * 6)"
shows  "p = 3 / 4"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Geoff and Trevor each roll a fair six-sided die.  What is the probability that the product of the numbers they roll is even? The final Answer is \dfrac34
 ### Proof
 There are $6 \times 6 = 36$ possible outcomes. The only way that they can roll an odd product is if both their rolls are odd. Since 3 of the 6 faces on each die are odd, this can occur in $3 \times 3 = 9$ ways.
 So a even product can occur in $36-9= 27$ ways, and the probability is thus $\dfrac{27}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac34}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> p"
and h1 : "p \<le> 1"
and h2 : "p = (\<Sum> (x, y) \<in> {1..6} \<times> {1..6}. if even (x * y) then 1 else 0) / (6 * 6)"
shows  "p = 3 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a probability $p$, where $0 \leq p \leq 1$, and $p$ is equal to the ratio of the number of even products when two dice are rolled (each die has faces numbered 1 to 6) to the total possible outcomes, find the value of $p$. The final answer is $\frac{3}{4}$.

theorem
fixes probability_even_product :: real
assumes h0 : "probability_even_product = (\<Sum> (x, y) \<in> ({1..6} \<times> {1..6}). if (x * y) mod 2 = 0 then 1 else 0) / 36"
shows  "probability_even_product = 3 / 4"

theorem
fixes probability_even_product :: real
assumes h0 : "probability_even_product = (\<Sum> (x, y) \<in> ({1..6} \<times> {1..6}). if (x * y) mod 2 = 0 then 1 else 0) / 36"
shows  "probability_even_product = 3 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: What is the probability of obtaining an even product when rolling two six-sided dice? The final answer is $\frac{3}{4}$.

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..6} . \<Sum> j \<in> {1..6} . if even (i * j) then 1 else 0) / (6 * 6)"
shows  "P = 3 / 4"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the probability $P$ that the product of two numbers, each randomly chosen from the set $\{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$, is even. The final answer is $\frac{3}{4}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "B = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h2 : "card A = 6"
and h3 : "card B = 6"
and h4 : "uniform_prob_on A"
and h5 : "uniform_prob_on B"
and h6 : "indep_events A B"
shows  "P { (a, b). a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> B \<and> even (a * b) } = 3/4"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Geoff and Trevor each roll a fair six-sided die.  What is the probability that the product of the numbers they roll is even? The final Answer is \dfrac34
 ### Proof
 There are $6 \times 6 = 36$ possible outcomes. The only way that they can roll an odd product is if both their rolls are odd. Since 3 of the 6 faces on each die are odd, this can occur in $3 \times 3 = 9$ ways.
 So a even product can occur in $36-9= 27$ ways, and the probability is thus $\dfrac{27}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac34}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "B = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h2 : "card A = 6"
and h3 : "card B = 6"
and h4 : "uniform_prob_on A"
and h5 : "uniform_prob_on B"
and h6 : "indep_events A B"
shows  "P { (a, b). a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> B \<and> even (a * b) } = 3/4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Two six-sided dice are rolled, with each die having the numbers 1 through 6. If the dice are fair and the rolls are independent events, find the probability that the product of the numbers rolled is even. The final answer is $\frac{3}{4}$.
